title: Blue Weaver
text:
Derek John "Blue" Weaver (born 11 March 1947) is a Welsh rock keyboardist, <a href="session%20musician">session musician</a>, songwriter and <a href="record%20producer">record producer</a>.
Career.
Weaver's career as a musician began as a co-founding member of 1960s Welsh rock band <a href="Amen%20Corner%20%28band%29">Amen Corner</a> and its successor <a href="Fair%20Weather">Fair Weather</a>. In 1971, Weaver joined <a href="Strawbs">Strawbs</a> after keyboardist <a href="Rick%20Wakeman">Rick Wakeman</a> departed to join <a href="Yes%20%28band%29">Yes</a>, contributing notable keyboard and <a href="Mellotron">Mellotron</a> parts on
"<a href="Grave%20New%20World">Grave New World</a>" and "<a href="Bursting%20at%20the%20Seams">Bursting at the Seams</a>", the bands' most successful and critically-acclaimed albums. Weaver left Strawbs in 1973 and toured with <a href="Mott%20the%20Hoople">Mott the Hoople</a> on their <a href="United%20States">US</a> <a href="concert%20tour">tour</a> with supporting act <a href="Queen%20%28band%29">Queen</a>. The following year, he toured with <a href="Streetwalkers">Streetwalkers</a>.
In 1975, former Amen Corner bandmate <a href="Dennis%20Bryon">Dennis Bryon</a>, who had begun playing drums in The Bee Gees backing band the year before, suggested Weaver as a replacement keyboardist for the band following the departure of Geoff Westley. The three-piece backing band of Weaver, Bryon and the perennial Bee Gees sideman, <a href="Alan%20Kendall">Alan Kendall</a>, played on the Bee Gees' albums "<a href="Main%20Course">Main Course</a>" (1975), "<a href="Children%20of%20the%20World">Children of the World</a>" (1976), "<a href="Here%20at%20Last...%20Bee%20Gees...%20Live">Here at Last... Bee Gees... Live</a>" (1977), and "<a href="Spirits%20Having%20Flown">Spirits Having Flown</a>" (1979), as well as the band's famous contributions on the "<a href="Saturday%20Night%20Fever%20%28soundtrack%29">Saturday Night Fever</a>" <a href="Soundtrack%20album">soundtrack</a>, including songs like "<a href="Jive%20Talkin%27">Jive Talkin'</a>" and "<a href="You%20Should%20Be%20Dancing">You Should Be Dancing</a>". Though not credited, Weaver greatly influenced the hit song "<a href="How%20Deep%20Is%20Your%20Love%20%28Bee%20Gees%20song%29">How Deep Is Your Love</a>"
As a songwriter and composer, Weaver was credited as a co-composer on <a href="Andy%20Gibb">Andy Gibb</a>'s hit song, "<a href="%28Our%20Love%29%20Don%27t%20Throw%20It%20All%20Away">(Our Love) Don't Throw It All Away</a>", as well as songs for <a href="Jimmy%20Ruffin">Jimmy Ruffin</a>'s 1980 album "Sunrise" with Robin Gibb as lyricist, including the hit single, "Hold On (To My Love)". Weaver composed the soundtrack for the film "<a href="Times%20Square%20%281980%20film%29">Times Square</a>", again collaborating with Robin Gibb on Gibb's duet with <a href="Marcella%20Detroit">Marcy Levy</a>, "Help Me". In 1980, Weaver worked as a session player for the <a href="Pet%20Shop%20Boys">Pet Shop Boys</a>. 
As of 2009, Weaver was a director and supporter of <a href="The%20Music%20Producers%20Guild">The Music Producers Guild</a>.
